76561198967321338.review:
This by far my favourite game .
Graphics: 10/10
Story: 9/10
Combat: 10/10
World: 20/10
Characters: 11/10
Replay value: 8/10
This game deserves the endless praise that it's getting , in my opinion The Witcher 3 : Wild Hunt is the closest a game has ever come to a masterpiece . 
The story is extremely interesting , it's very well written and it's fun in every past bit , sometimes they drag for way to long . In the simplest way this Witcher's story is a series of clichés extremely well executed 
The characters are outstanding , every SINGLE character is morally grey (even you, Geralt) . Every peasant is acting differently depending on the area you are (in Velen everyone talks with a certain dialect  like they don't know grammar , they don't and in Toussaint everyone is happy and speak in a "poetic" dialect).All the characters have a story to tell(biggest example:Bloody Baron), every choise you make matters in some way or another , so if you do the said thing the inhabitants of this village will treat you differently.All and all the characters are great.

Combat , here is the tricky part . The combat has mixed opinions (sometimes people say it's too difficult or it's way too stail) , but they  don't understand that the Witcher 3 is a game of preparation, you will need to grind a bit for the oils ,potions , decotions, bombs , armor and swords it's (i hate to say this) "realistic".You can't just be said "Go kill the [said monster]" , you will need to locate it(using Witcher senses) , prepare the right stuff and then go kill it , you can't just storm the boss thinking that you will easily win(unless you are playing the easy modes).

The world of this game is outstanding. The attention to detail is amazing. Each area has the appropriate theme :
Velen is full of poor people , it's sad , it's full of death and it's depressing , But that is the point of Velen it's No man's land that is ruled by bandits, killeres and thieves.
Novigrad and oxenfurt are similar it's full of death , not this time by war but by torture , supremacy and tyranny. Skellige is a place of vikings divided by clans that are constantly fighting for the throne , so that's why every village is disconnected by another , the people there are strong , famed for their wrath so it is logical that they don't have or need the comforts of the continent. White orchard is a small little place that everything seems fine but it isn't, the villagers aren't happy that they have been conquered by Nilfgard , because they know ehat they are capable of , but they aren't warriors , they are farmers so they seem oppressed.Toussaint is  a place of "pictures" , a rose is similar to Toussaint , it looks beautiful and happy , but it isn't , the roots are painful and dark.
So i recommend to whoever reads this review to by this "almost grandmasterpiece" of a game

Possibly my favourite game of all time! The story feels bigger and more exciting as you progress, you have fun, quick little side quests, cool contracts where you defeat monsters, and very interesting side quests that were as intricate as main campaign quests. These intricate side quests assist the world building that make the main campaign more exciting.

The combat isn't too interesting, but can be enjoyable. There's definitely a few ways to make the combat kinda easy! But it is pretty enjoyable even when you feel like you're not doing what the game devs exactly wanted the player to do!

Most appealing parts are: 1 - The RPG aspect, where you make decisions and see their consequences. It gives a lot of responsibility to the player and takes you into the world. And that brings me to the other most appealing part: 2 - The world within this game. The environment, the music, and the character and monster encounters you make immerse you in this world, and ain't that just a sign of a really good game??!! It sure is!

9/10 - Great game!

76561198155504573.review:
Played through the main game about a year after launch on PS4 and enjoyed it a lot. Came back for a second go because the Ultimate Edition was on sale and I never got a chance to touch basis with any of the DLC so I figured why not for the price. What saddened me to see was the game filled with graphical bugs. Thankfully not much at all has directly hindered gameplay, I can still run and play the game just fine, averaging about 100fps on high settings. But there are a lot of texture loading issues, sometimes I'll load the game up and it'll take noticeably longer to get everything up to par visually. Long enough where I'll literally just be playing the game with flat play doh looking textures until it all loads up. Terrain suffers from these same bugs, sometimes section of the road or grass will randomly just clip up out of the ground and start flashing. Things I shouldn't have to expect out of a 6 year old game that has had ample time to be cleaned up and especially after the games launch was already a little rough. These are really my biggest complaints which is why after this long hiatus of Witcher for me, it compelled me to write a review and at least talk about these things. I understand not everyone will have the same experience as me, and that's fair but this is my experience so that's all I can speak on. 

The game is great though. Combat is fun and fulfilling, it inserts enough mechanics to not feel like a hack and slash but still keep the combat entertaining and not overbearing to learn. Graphics still hold up to this day although the face mocap is a bit wonky. I honestly couldn't tell you where face mocap was in 2015 so I can't honestly criticize too much for that at the time of this review. 

Story is riveting and will keep you engaged especially if you were already a fan of the fantasy rpg genre. Interesting characters and some pretty meaningful dialogue not just in the story altering options, but the game itself is generally written well all around. Side quests have a very high level of attention to detail in the story lines. Some branching off into multiple quests either solo or with another NPC you get to learn about along the way. (Do the Keira storyline)

RPG mechanics are deep and thoughtful, alchemy and crafting will be your best friend especially at higher difficulty levels. Skill tree is deep but not overbearing, it strikes a great balance between being able to min/max builds if you want, or just throw points all over the place and still have fun. There are obviously optimal builds or what some would say are the best. But no matter how you play, you will have fun with this game. 

So all in all, The Witcher 3 is a great game. Sadly as a consumer I cannot recommend it based off of my experience with the technical bugs. If you can get it on sale like I did for $10 and feel the value is worth fighting through the bugs, then sure. And for that price I'd say pick it up at least to have it, you can get it with all the DLC. But at full price I don't think its fair to sell a product that still functions like this even so long after launch. Most of the bugs didn't seem to be present until a little after the refund period ended and at that point I was already into the game again. If these issues become fixed, then I can highly recommend this game but not with the technical bugs it currently still has at this point.

Bought this game on sale along with DLCs for about $10USD. Been playing for 8 hours, and I've ONLY JUST NOW started really getting into the main campaign and traveling through different regions. I've spent more than 6+ hours in just THE FIRST REGION. That's how much content there is in this game. Yeah, I may not be the best at this game, but I can already tell that this is going to be one hell of an experience to enjoy.

-Combat system is perfectly difficult to master, I know I haven't yet.
-Enemies are complex and make you really feel like a Witcher when you learn how to eventually deal with them using past experiences. It comes naturally.
-Open world is truly OPEN. I rarely use fast traveling, I mainly just ride on horseback to find loot and NPC interactions instead of just skipping over it instantly.
-Graphics are stunning, even with a weaker sided processor.
-Characters feel genuine and alive with real motives.
-Story is long and intricate, from what I can tell.
-You don't need much knowledge from the other 2 past Witcher games to have a good time.
-You don't need to have much knowledge of this world in general to have a good experience, you'll learn in due time.

Game has some obvious flaws, but, in all honesty, no real game changing or memorable cons I can think of off the top of my head.

I'd give it a rating of a 19/20 from what I can tell so far, it's up to you to decide for yourself. Have fun, hope this helped!

76561199041702415.review: Although I have not played much of this game yet, I can say without a doubt that this is a great game. The opening tutorial fit in quite well with the story, making it seem as though I really was training a child, where instead it was training me. From there, the open world is pretty much completely open right off the bat. There are some limitations as to how much of the map is accessible at the start, most of it is open. The graphics are pretty good. The graphics nowadays look a bit outdated compared to recent games as this game is now almost 6 years old. The writing is excellent so far, the story, while a bit hard to grasp at first as this is my first foray into the franchise, makes perfect sense. The controls are a bit hit and miss in my opinion and fares much better with a controller. The same goes for combat, while fun and not too repetitive, the combat system can be a bit clunky and feel like old school Diablo. The optimization of this port is amazing also. I run this at max settings, rendered in 4K, although downscaled to 108p as I only have a 1080p monitor, and I keep a very good 60 FPS all the time. I understand that my rig would have been a beast when this came out, but this is still well optimized. (I have an Intel i5 10400F, GTX 1660 Super, 16 Gigs DDR4 2666Mhz RAM) I do highly recommend this game, even when its at its full price of $39.99, and even the GOTY edition is a good deal, it may seem expensive, but give it time I picked up GOTY edition for 9.99 USD. I do give CDPR great praise for this game, although it may have had just as shady development as THAT game (You know the one) I still think this is a genuinely enjoyable game for the price.

76561198136131640.review:
43 hours to complete the game, going from someone who sort of touched witcher 2 to knowing this game well.

Story; I stopped following 25 hours in... it just became so much dialogue, and so much to follow that at that point I just wanted to fight the final fights and see the ending. But until that point, and things that tied in at the end, pretty good.

Gameplay; god damn Ciri is so much fun to play as. I think the brief amount of time I enjoyed playing with her, I had way more fun than any other time with Gerald. Still, super fun, great mechanics and feels super fluid.

Ending; idk if I did too many side quests before entering final stages of the game, but the last fights were far too easy. I am in no way a great gamer, I don't sit with dorito dust on my desk. But I still beat all final bosses easily in one go. Somehow the anticipation made it out as if they were going to be the biggest challenge of them all, and would be insane fights. Kinda dissapointing.

Gwent; god damn this was the most fun I had in this game. 10/10
